title: Floral Arrangements
headline: Master the techniques used to create spectacular designs with flowers in this free online floral arrangement course.
description: This free online course teaches you how to arrange flowers beautifully, either professionally or for fun. Whether you are preparing them for weddings, funerals or other events, it is important to know the meaning and symbolism of different flowers. These small but crucial details can make you stand out as an efficient and caring florist. We provide helpful tips and tricks that keep floral arrangements in line with traditions and proper etiquette.
courseDescription:
Florists have a special relationship with flowers as each bloom has its own natural characteristics and personality. Some types of flowers get along well together while others do not. Did you know some flowers can flourish and grow to music? Some of them even have their own preferred music. An excellent way to start learning the art of flower arrangement is to select a single flower in season or a favourite and let it guide you. We provide helpful tricks and procedures that will help you to carefully choose what the world about you has to offer, such as containers, floral and plant materials. Once you have made such decisions, it will be important to remember how and where the result will be displayed.

As you hone your skills, you might feel ready to tackle a more demanding and specialized field of floristry, like arranging flowers for a wedding. The meanings of flowers are often inspirational for romantic couples and some blossoms might have special sentimental meanings. Paying attention to such fine but important details can help you stand apart from the competition. Equally, understanding the different flower species, their meaning and symbolism can add a spiritual or emotional dimension to your floral arrangement. This course also covers specific methods that can help you to advertize and promote your business.

While many think about happy and exciting events associated with flowers, experienced florists know that one of their most sorrowful tasks is preparing arrangements for funerals. The loss of a loved one is usually difficult for grieving relatives who can experience mixed emotions, including confusion and anger. Condolence flowers may cause confusion and we explain how to arrange them in line with respectful funeral traditions and etiquette. Anyone interested in floristry can gain a lot from this course as we provide specific techniques and methods behind making floral arrangements, choosing appropriate flowers for different events and understanding flower meanings. Sign up to learn more, whether you are a budding florist or want to express yourself with nature’s beauty.

Start Course Now

• Learning Outcomes

  •   By the end of this module you will be able to:
    • Recognise the different containers and vessels available for plants.
    • Describe how to create floral centrepieces in shallow containers.
    • State the tools needed to make an arrangement.
    • Recall the steps to create a flower container arrangement.
    • Arrange and prepare your flowers.
    • Explain several ways of using container displays.

  • Making Floral Arrangements

  • It is a florist’s job to make floral arrangements. There are many tricks and techniques that are involved in creating each arrangement. Florists use a huge variety of flowers, plants and foliage for their creations. There are many sources from where you may get your raw materials for cut flowers:
    • Flowers gathered from the garden
    • Flower bought from a florist
    • Flowers collected at the roadside
    • Flowers borrowed from a neighbour
  • But no matter what species of flowers you utilise, or where you buy or collect them, each flower will have its own natural characteristics and individual personality. Some types of flowers get along well together, while others do not.

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are the following:
    • There are many sources from where you may get your raw materials for cut flowers: gathered from the garden, bought from a florist, collected at the roadside or borrowed from a neighbour.
    • If a display is for your own premises, consider the mood and the colour of the room in which it will be displayed and also the available space. A small bowl of daisies may look exquisite on a low coffee table, but very lonely if shown on a long dining table. An arrangement of tall irises will brighten a dark spot but cramp the conversation at a dinner table.
    • Remember, that arrangements to mark a special occasion are much better prepared one day before so that the flowers and plant material develop a comfortable and settled appearance. If you are arranging a display as a gift, then consider to whom it will be gifted and also the spirit of their celebration, or their loss.
    • If in doubt, one colour and one species, the quicker and more efficiently each step is executed; and the less that the flowers and plants are handled, the longer that the flowers and the arrangement will sustain.
    • The type of vase you choose depends on how formal the arrangement is as well as its size and shape. Your choices of vase shape include the column vase, flare vase, urn vase, bubble vase, cylinder vase, square vase, decanter, rounded vase, rectangle vase and coloured vase.
    • The basic equipment to create amazing arrangements: tape, floral adhesive, vases & containers, floral foam, wire, plant Food & preservatives, cutting tools, pins & pin cushions, water picks and wood picks.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • By the end of this module you will be able to:
    • Recall the history of the corsage and boutonniere.
    • State the materials needed for arrangements and bouquets.
    • Explain how to make a hand-tied bouquet.

  • Vase Arrangement Introduction

  • Before beginning to arrange the foliage and flowers, cut the stems at an angle; until they are arranged, keep all of the stems as long as possible. Split any of the woody stems, remove the pollen from lilies (if being used) and give all the material a long drink in clean deep water.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Example Materials Needed:
    • Foliage (2 types)
    • Flowers (4 types)
    • A flared vase
    • Sterilising tablet or flower food (if a clear glass vase is being used)
    • Chicken wire (this is optional if you’re using an opaque vase)
    • Florist’s scissors or similar.

  • Making a Hand-Tied Bouquet

  • Bouquets of flowers that can be carried include the corsage and the nosegay. In the mid-19th century, a nosegay, or posy (a small mixed bunch of flowers), was very much in fashion. Messages of love were regularly spelt out by the nosegay flowers, for the “language of flowers’ was regularly studied at that time. Via the sending of these floral symbols, courtships progressed. 

    There is a methodical sequence to arranging a hand-tied bouquet. As one adds the types of flowers in a similar sequence, while turning the growing bunch gradually in the same direction each time a flower or a stem of foliage is added, then this should ensure that one will not position the same flower type next to each other as the bouquet progresses.
  • The binding position will determine the bouquet size: if the stems are held lower down, then the bouquet will be looser and the stems will be longer. A binding point slightly higher up, say by holding the bunch about halfway or two-thirds up the stems, should automatically give a more compact bouquet as a result.

    Materials Needed:
    - Flowers x 5 species: e.g. (pale pink single roses, pink cockscombs, mauve throatwort, masterwort and dark pink calla lilies)
    - Foliage
    - Raffia or garden string
    - Florist’s scissors or similar

  • How to Make a Corsage or Boutonniere

  • The corsage became extremely popular in the 20th century. The flower blooms are only used in a corsage. Rather than a nosegay, an admirer would frequently send a lady a gardenia, an orchid, or a little bunch of flowers that were wired and intended to be worn on the waist, on the shoulder, or on a wrist, and even attached to a handbag that was carried. Generally for a Boutonniere:
    • Wires are pushed in via the calyx (part of the flower that’s usually green and outermost), then bent to shape the flowers forward or to one side. The ends can then be tied together with tape or ribbon.
    • Foliage or greens threaded crosswise can, with a similar technique, be added. A ribbon bow is often used to complete the corsage, but you may use any binding material according to taste.
    • It is preferable if one uses a hardy flower with a larger bloom, like a rose or a miniature calla lily, for they can better survive the handling.

  • Hanging Baskets

  • What is lovely about hanging baskets is the drama and lavish extravagance of bright cascades of flower and foliage hanging down.

    They are a great chance to freely experiment with imaginative juxtapositions, including houseplants. Hanging baskets can be themed according to what is currently available, or generally classified into three distinct styles. One style may be a gentle blend of flowers and foliage, another style may be sensuously fragrant, while a third could be strictly foliage.

    All three are naturally luxuriant and impactful, yet simple to make, and should last right through a summer season. It pays off to think big regarding hanging baskets, for the larger the basket, then the greater amount of moisture it retains, which keeps your garden basket creation in much better condition than a small basket.

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are the following:
    • Before beginning to arrange the foliage and flowers, cut the stems at an angle; until they are arranged, keep all of the stems as long as possible when arranging a vase. 
    • The steps to making a floral vase arrangement include preparing the flowers & vase, arranging your stems in the vase, adding more foliage, adding flowers, checking the arrangement from the side and adding more flowers. 
    • Bouquets that can be carried include the corsage and the nosegay. In the mid-19th century, a nosegay, or posy (a small mixed bunch of flowers), was very much in fashion. There is a methodical sequence to arranging a hand-tied bouquet. 
    • To create a hand-tied bouquet you will need to do the following in order: pick a focal flower, add a second flower, continue to place flowers, trim the stems, view the bouquet from above, secure with string or raffia and trim the stem ends. 
    • Hanging baskets can be themed according to what is currently available, or generally classified into three distinct styles. One style may be a gentle blend of flowers and foliage, another style may be sensuously fragrant, while a third could be strictly foliage.

    • Hanging baskets can be themed according to what is currently available, or generally classified into three distinct styles. One style may be a gentle blend of flowers and foliage, another style may be sensuously fragrant, while a third could be strictly foliage.

  • Learning Outcomes

  •   By the end of this module you will be able to:
    • Indicate the requirements needed to be a wedding florist.
    • Execute strategies to promote yourself using your portfolio.
    • Describe how to create floral decorations and décor for wedding ceremonies and receptions.
    • Identify adequate flowers to use for a wedding. 
    • Recall the tools needed for a wedding bouquet.
    • Discuss several ways to preserve the bouquet.

  • Wedding and Bridal Floristry: What it Needs

  • This is a highly specialised field of floristry and you need to have several years’ experience to be able to establish yourself as a wedding florist. You would be wise to work as an assistant or helper with an established or well-known wedding florist before you embark on your own journey in this area. 

    There is a lot to learn before you can expect to land your first bride and serve her and her wedding party well. You need to learn the language of flowers. Yes, there is a language of flowers, but whether or not anyone at a wedding is conversant with this language is a different question. 

    The meanings of flowers are often an inspirational source for many romantic couples. Equally, understanding the different flower species, the meaning of flowers and also what their symbolism is, can add a spiritual or an emotional dimension to one’s choice of floral arrangements. Magnolia signifies love for nature and stephanotis means marital happiness.
  • In the Victorian era, the Language of Flowers became a romantic code for lovers in their correspondence, for flowers came to replace words. If you wish to suffuse a wedding with flowers rich in symbolism, then further research this interesting aspect of floral decoration and choose which symbolisms mean the maximum to you or your clients.

  • Meeting with Clients

  • It would be naive to think that all couples who are recently engaged would know how to liaise and work with a flower designer. Even though there are infinite numbers of wedding planning articles, books, and magazines regarding how to plan a perfect wedding, plus so many internet blogs, occasionally a future bride will ask if it is necessary to meet with a floral arranger in order to receive a proposal.

    Meeting a floral designer is essential, unless the client is planning a destination wedding and, even so, at the least a
    telephone interview is highly recommended. If the designer asks the right questions, every bride will come up with exactly what she requires. Rather than being overwhelmed with images via Pinterest, most designers absolutely prefer to be engaged in a gentle discovery of what exactly the bride likes.
  • Ask questions like:
    • What is your favourite flower?
    • What are your preferred colours?
    • Have you been at a wedding that you loved? And why?
    • What colours or flowers do you not like?
  • A couple should be able to answer such questions. If not, they must research their answers before meeting a designer, and have at least some decent idea of what it is they are after!

  • Flowers for Immediate Members of a Wedding Party

  • The bridesmaid bouquets are generally smaller than the bouquet of the bride. The bouquet of a maid of honour can be a little larger than the junior bridesmaids. The corsages to be made for mothers and for grandmothers do not need to be identical. The corsage colour should preferably theme with the colour of the bridesmaid dresses.

    Would the bridesmaid party prefer a pinned corsage, or a wrist corsage? There are so many floral options for a corsage such as orchids, roses, camellias, gardenias, or mini-carnations. You should get all these decisions out of the way first before you begin with the next phase of your consultation.
  • General guidelines for who should receive wedding flowers:
    • The Bride – the bridal bouquet.
    • Smaller Bouquets – the bridesmaids.
    • Mothers and Grandmothers – the bride’s leaving corsage.
    • Flower Girl – flower basket and flower halo.
    • Optional boutonnieres or corsage.
    • Groom’s Boutonniere.
    • Groomsmen’s Boutonnieres.
    • Other close family members that are not in the immediate family wedding party.

    • Another popular choice is for contrasting colours.

      For example:
      Pink flowers do look gorgeous with a pink bridesmaid dress. At the other end of the colour spectrum, blue flowers will attract great attention. Whether a bride chooses contrasting, matching, or sentimental colours, a purchase of different flowers and colours allows for a custom bouquet design in any one, or variety of shades. 

      Brides should also feel free to experiment with the colour combination of the bouquet ribbon and the flowers. Given that the traditional ribbon colour is white, the contrast of the white or off-white flowers against the green stems will, stylistically, tie any bouquet with a dress.     • A bride could choose virtually any colour for her bouquet ribbon:
      - Green ribbon makes a bouquet appear as if the stems are quite natural and not at all wrapped.

      - The ribbon may also match the flowers rather than contrast them.

      - If you want uniformity, then select a ribbon which matches the colour of your blossoms.

      - If there is colour variety in your bouquet, then select a ribbon colour which matches any of the blooms. Whatever colour is matched will make the corresponding flowers pop.

      Whatever the flower or ribbon colours you may choose, when buying flowers for a bouquet make sure to buy them with medium or long stems.

    • To make a bouquet easy to hold, the bride will require the bouquet to have ample stem length. The longer your stems then the more elegant is the bouquet. It is far easier to cut down any long stems from the fresh flowers stock, than it is to lengthen shorter stems and secure them to a bouquet.

      If the flowers you want for a bouquet grow in clusters, then purchase the complete stalk or spray. Long flowers are lovely when cascading down from the front of a flower bouquet.

      Always buy more flowers than you estimate requiring, for fresh cut flowers in your hand may well inspire some new creative ideas or some additional bouquets. Equally first time bouquet makers may have damages or a change of mind. Extra flowers will allow one to change at the last moment without a rush to buy more blooms or have them delivered.

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are the following:
    • Show off your knowledge of flowers and their meanings to captivate your client as well as inform them subtly that you know what you are talking about as you are the expert. Be pleasant and informative with any enquiries that come in.
    • Post details about your business on social media and the internet. Create a special social media campaign for weddings. There are special social media pages, forums and communities dedicated to weddings. Search them and regularly contribute to them.
    • Portfolios are an absolute essential for any florist, but more so for a wedding florist. Use images, photos, idea sketches that you may have created, to populate your portfolio. This helps to boost the confidence of the clients regarding your capabilities.
    • Most designers prefer to be engaged in a gentle discovery of what exactly the bride likes. Ask questions like: what is your favourite flower, what are your preferred colours, have you been at a wedding that you loved & why and what colours or flowers do you not like.
    • The important point about an upfront approach to meeting with a client is that it saves everybody’s energy and time. The client can decide if they have an adequate budget, and the designer can be spared the effort and time of making a proposal for somebody who was not going to be a client in the first place.

The client can decide if they have an adequate budget, and the designer can be spared the effort and time of making a proposal for somebody who was not going to be a client in the first place.

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are the following:
    • Show off your knowledge of flowers and their meanings to captivate your client as well as inform them subtly that you know what you are talking about as you are the expert. Be pleasant and informative with any enquiries that come in.
    • Post details about your business on social media and the internet. Create a special social media campaign for weddings. There are special social media pages, forums and communities dedicated to weddings. Search them and regularly contribute to them.
    • Portfolios are an absolute essential for any florist, but more so for a wedding florist. Use images, photos, idea sketches that you may have created, to populate your portfolio. This helps to boost the confidence of the clients regarding your capabilities.

  • Learning Outcomes

  •   By the end of this module you will be able to:
    • Indicate the meaning of funeral flowers.
    • Describe various types of funeral flower arrangements.
    • Identify flowers used in funeral arrangements and their symbolism.
    • Discuss religious sentiments and traditions regarding funeral flowers.
    • List the materials needed to make a funeral wreath.
    • State the methods used to preserve a wreath.

  • Funeral Flowers

  • The loss of a loved one is usually such a difficult time for the bereaved. Emotions can be oscillating between grief and sadness, confusion and anger. Sending the bereaved sympathy flowers, plants or baskets is always a kind and compassionate gesture. However, it may be quite confusing to know what flowers or arrangement to send, where to send it, and to whom it should be sent.

  • Types of Funeral Flower Arrangements

    • New Tab
      Enter your text here..
      Enter your text here..
    • Standing Flower Spray
      Standing sprays are generally displayed upon an easel and typically positioned near a casket in a prominent location.

      They are usually forwarded directly to a funeral home, a mortuary, or to the church for the ceremony.
      Standing sprays are generally displayed upon an easel and typically positioned near a casket in a prominent location.

      They are usually forwarded directly to a funeral home, a mortuary, or to the church for the ceremony.
    • Flower Wreaths, Hearts, and Crosses
      These styles of floral arrangements are also displayed upon an easel in a prominent spot for maximum effect. A standing flower heart or a standing flower cross is so-called since they are designed in that particular shape. Flower wreaths will be typically circular in shape while bringing a special meaning to a ceremony, for the circle shape of a wreath is a symbol of the infinite wheel of life.
      These styles of floral arrangements are also displayed upon an easel in a prominent spot for maximum effect. A standing flower heart or a standing flower cross is so-called since they are designed in that particular shape. Flower wreaths will be typically circular in shape while bringing a special meaning to a ceremony, for the circle shape of a wreath is a symbol of the infinite wheel of life.
    • Casket Sprays
      A casket spray is placed directly on top of a coffin; they can be designed in a variety of sizes, such as the full casket and half-casket sizes, and these are the most favoured. A full casket spray is suitable for a closed casket service, while a half casket spray is generally used for an open casket ceremony; the spray is positioned on the closed section of the casket.

      These styles of floral displays are generally sent from the direct family members of the departed. Large and flat bouquets of long-stem plant material are called sprays. They can be carried or positioned on a casket or at a tomb as a commemorative display.

A full casket spray is suitable for a closed casket service, while a half casket spray is generally used for an open casket ceremony; the spray is positioned on the closed section of the casket.

      These styles of floral displays are generally sent from the direct family members of the departed. Large and flat bouquets of long-stem plant material are called sprays. They can be carried or positioned on a casket or at a tomb as a commemorative display.
    • Funeral Basket
      A funeral basket is appropriate and suitable for delivery directly to a funeral home, a mortuary, or to the church.

      Floral funeral baskets are designed in a decorative basket or a similar container and leave a lovely impression.
      A funeral basket is appropriate and suitable for delivery directly to a funeral home, a mortuary, or to the church.

      Floral funeral baskets are designed in a decorative basket or a similar container and leave a lovely impression.
    • Dish Gardens or Plants
      A dish garden is an assortment of plants, either greens, blooms or an assortment of both. It is a tiny garden set to grow in a shallow bowl or dish. The dish garden is often landscaped to echo a natural scene, it’s a miniature ecosystem.

      The green or blooming plants may also be used individually as a message of sympathy. Either dish gardens or plants are quite suitable to be forwarded directly to a service or to the deceased’s family’s residence. Dish Gardens or plants are also a very suitable choice to send to a workplace as a sympathy gift.

      The green or blooming plants may also be used individually as a message of sympathy. Either dish gardens or plants are quite suitable to be forwarded directly to a service or to the deceased’s family’s residence. Dish Gardens or plants are also a very suitable choice to send to a workplace as a sympathy gift.
    • Flower Blankets
      A flower blanket is a lovely adornment for the top of a coffin at a final farewell ceremony. Sometimes it's draped across a casket at a funeral. Blankets are constructed by stretching burlap on a frame, then covering this with a layer of flattened ferns, and then delicate asparagus fern (Sprengeri) is also added. This surface of fern is then covered with flower blooms, which have been threaded with wire and which are fastened to the underside.

      Flowers sent to commemorate the passing of an infant or a child are often a smaller display than customary funeral floral arrangements for adults. At a child’s ceremony, designs are often in the shape of a children’s toy. The child’s ceremony colour scheme can be soft pastels or bright sunny colours. Funeral displays appropriate for a child’s ceremony include arrangements in a vase, a standing spray, a wreath, or a cross.

  • How to Make a Funeral Wreath

  • Garlands are bands of plant material and flowers that are woven or, in some other way, attached together. Garlands are not arranged in any container. A wreath is basically a circular garland. If it is worn around the head, it is called a chaplet. Garlands draped in loops are known as festoons or swags.

    Wreaths are much more than circles of evergreens or flowers. Historically they date to ancient times. Persia, Greece, and ancient Rome were among many civilisations that worshipped evergreens, such as holly or laurel, which they believed represented immortality.

    Even these days the symbolism is still evident. The circularity of the shape for both Christmas and sympathy or funeral wreaths may indicate the circle of life, as the ring is without beginning or end.

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are the following:
    • Lilies are usually chosen as the default flowers for funerals, as will suggest that the spirit of the deceased individual has returned to a blissful state of purity. A peace lily plant represents rebirth and innocence of a departed soul from the mundane physical world of dualities to the singularity of purity.
    • Roses are also an extremely common and suitable flower for a funeral ceremony and message of sympathy. Each colour of a rose has its own slightly different association. No matter what its colour, the orchid has a universal interpretation, “I will always love you.”
    • The classic carnation is so regularly used in a standing spray and a funeral wreath. As with other species, each colour of the carnation has a particular meaning. Hyacinths are generally included in a display of assorted flowers. There is a variety of notions regarding their meaning, ranging from “you are included in our prayers”, to a deep expression of anguish and loss. 
    • A framed photograph of the deceased can be placed in the middle of a wreath that is on display at a funeral home. Consider writing the title of the person (Brother, Aunt, or Friend) onto a small section of the satin ribbon with a glitter glue pen and let it dry. Now position the ribbon across the centre hole in the wreath, and attach it to the wreath with a greening pin or a pearl corsage pin.

    • Lilies are usually chosen as the default flowers for funerals, as will suggest that the spirit of the deceased individual has returned to a blissful state of purity. A peace lily plant represents rebirth and innocence of a departed soul from the mundane physical world of dualities to the singularity of purity.
    • Roses are also an extremely common and suitable flower for a funeral ceremony and message of sympathy. Each colour of a rose has its own slightly different association. No matter what its colour, the orchid has a universal interpretation, “I will always love you.”
    • The classic carnation is so regularly used in a standing spray and a funeral wreath. As with other species, each colour of the carnation has a particular meaning. Hyacinths are generally included in a display of assorted flowers. There is a variety of notions regarding their meaning, ranging from “you are included in our prayers”, to a deep expression of anguish and loss. 
    • A framed photograph of the deceased can be placed in the middle of a wreath that is on display at a funeral home. Consider writing the title of the person (Brother, Aunt, or Friend) onto a small section of the satin ribbon with a glitter glue pen and let it dry. Now position the ribbon across the centre hole in the wreath, and attach it to the wreath with a greening pin or a pearl corsage pin.
